Do you have any questions about the ingredients required for this recipe?
what's kosher salt?

Kosher salt or kitchen salt is coarse edible salt without common additives such as iodine. Used in cooking and not at the table, it consists mainly of sodium chloride and may include anticaking agents.

provenance.paragraph_text: Kosher salt or kitchen salt is coarse edible salt without common additives such as iodine. Used in cooking and not at the table, it consists mainly of sodium chloride and may include anticaking agents.

Before going to the next step, I want to highlight that this first step is crucial when making gnocchi.
why is it crucial?
S parisian gnocchi are somewhat of an oddity in the Western repertoire, in that they're made with a hot water dough—much like Chinese-style dumpling or stretched noodle dough.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Parisian gnocchi are somewhat of an oddity in the Western repertoire, in that they're made with a hot water dough—much like Chinese-style dumpling or stretched noodle dough.

conversation.utterance: With a hot water dough, By adding flour directly to boiling water, you actually end up not only denaturing the proteins, but smashing them into small pieces.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: A hot water dough, on the other hand, works differently.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: By adding flour directly to boiling water, you actually end up not only denaturing the proteins, but smashing them into small pieces.

conversation.utterance: Some degree of gluten can still form, but because cooked proteins aren't nearly as stretchy or clingy as raw ones, you won't get anywhere near the elasticity of a cold-water dough.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Some degree of gluten can still form, but because cooked proteins aren't nearly as stretchy or clingy as raw ones, you won't get anywhere near the elasticity of a cold-water dough.

conversation.utterance: Adding butter and other fats to the dough will further diminish its gluten-forming abilities.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Adding butter and other fats to the dough will further diminish its gluten-forming abilities.

conversation.utterance: As a result, a pâte à choux dough isn't stretchy or bouncy; its more malleable and supple.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: As a result, a pâte à choux dough isn't stretchy or bouncy; its more malleable and supple, kind of like Play-Do.

conversation.utterance: This fact that a pâte à choux dough isn't stretchy or bouncy is essential when making Parisian Gnocchi
where do they come from?
Would you like to know about the origin of this dish?
please

So the word "gnocchi" may be derived from the Italian word "nocchio", meaning a knot in wood, or from "nocca" (meaning knuckle). It has been a traditional type of Italian pasta of (probable) Middle Eastern origin since Roman times. It was introduced by the Roman legions during the expansion of the empire into the countries of the European continent. Parisian Gnocchi or "gnocchis à la parisienne", is a regional French variety comprising gnocchi formed of choux pastry served with Béchamel sauce.

provenance.page_title: Gnocchi
provenance.paragraph_text: The word "gnocchi" may be derived from the Italian word "nocchio", meaning a knot in wood, or from "nocca" (meaning knuckle). It has been a traditional type of Italian pasta of (probable) Middle Eastern origin since Roman times. It was introduced by the Roman legions during the expansion of the empire into the countries of the European continent. In Roman times, gnocchi were made from a semolina porridge-like dough mixed with eggs, and are still found in similar forms today, particularly the oven-baked "gnocchi alla romana" and Sardinia's "malloreddus" which do not contain eggs.

provenance.page_title: Gnocchi
provenance.paragraph_text: The name is also used in France in the dish known as "gnocchis à la parisienne", a hot dish comprising gnocchi formed of choux pastry served with Béchamel sauce. A specialty of Nice, the "gnocchi de tantifla a la nissarda", is made with potatoes, wheat flour, eggs and "blette" (Swiss chard), which is also used for the "tourte de blette". "La merda dé can" is longer than the original gnocchi.

provenance.page_title: Gnocchi
provenance.paragraph_text: Regional varieties.:France.

conversation.utterance: next
Can you tell me what's the difference between cold water dough and hot water dough and why that's important in this context?
hot water not only denatures the proteins it also smashes them into small pieces which cold water doesn't and we need that to happen to get the elasticity required

That's correct! And that's really important in this context.  The beauty of a hot water dough is that, as you can see, it doesn't bounce back as much as a cold water dough does. As the gnocchi go through their primary poaching step in simmering water, water vapor and trapped gases will expand, causing the gnocchi to inflate slightly.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: The beauty of a hot water dough is that, as you can see, it doesn't bounce back as much as a cold water dough does.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: This is important: as the gnocchi go through their primary poaching step in simmering water, water vapor and trapped gases will expand, causing the gnocchi to inflate slightly.

conversation.utterance: This change in density caused by expanding gases is what causes them to gently float to the surface of the pot as they poach.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: This change in density caused by expanding gases is what causes them to gently float to the surface of the pot as they poach.

conversation.utterance: If we were to try and make gnocchi with a cold water dough we'd end up with dense, chewy nubs that taste more like damp bread.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: If we were to try and make gnocchi with a cold water dough, one with plenty of springy, elastic gluten, we'd have a heck of a time getting those gnocchi hot enough to expand to the point where they come out nice and airy; Instead, we'd end up with dense, chewy nubs that taste more like damp bread.

conversation.utterance: thank you
Are you planning to use a stand mixer or a wooden spoon in this step?
a stand mixer

That's a good choice. There's absolutely no detectable difference between the wooden spoon and the stand-mixer method, provided you beat extremely vigorously. However, if you're even slightly lax with the hand-beating, then the stand mixer method will produce superior results every time.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Cooked side-by-side, there's absolutely no detectable difference between the wooden spoon and the stand-mixer method, provided you beat extremely vigorously.

provenance.paragraph_text: If you're even slightly lax with the hand-beating, then the stand mixer method will produce superior results every time.

User moved to section "Step 4".
why just 1 minute?
So the goal is to pipe and cut as many gnocchi as you possibly can within about a minute so that the last gnocchi that drops in won't be too far behind the first one that entered the pool.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: The goal is to pipe and cut as many gnocchi as you possibly can within about a minute, so that the last gnocchi that drops in won't be too far behind the first one that entered the pool.

conversation.utterance: However, before you transfer the dough into a piping bag or a zipper-lock bag with the corner snipped off, you should let it rest for 20 minutes or so.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: To do it, you transfer the dough into a piping bag or a zipper-lock bag with the corner snipped off, then let it rest for 20 minutes or so.

why a rimmed sheet?
Once the gnocchi are poached you want to let them rest. Therefore, you can transfer them to a rimmed baking sheet, toss them in a bit of oil, and let them cool down.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: The beauty of these gnocchi is that once they're poached, you can transfer them to a rimmed baking sheet, toss them in a bit of oil, and let them cool down.
